fr:title.text: Lecture 23: regular languages and Kleene’s theorem

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Lecture 23: regular languages and Kleene’s theorem

fr:mainmatter.html:p: These lecture notes were prepared by Jon Sterling by adapting prior notes created by Andrew Pitts that I inherited from Frank Stajano.

In previous lectures, we have seen two apparently different ways to generate a class of formal languages: by means of regular expressions and by means of finite automata. The goal of this lecture is to see that all these classes of language coincide, which is a theorem due to Stephen Kleene; to start with, we define regular languages below.
A formal language is called regular if it is equal to \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (R\right )\mathclose {}} for some regular expression R.
Using a bit of non-standard terminology, we give a name to the class of languages that can be recognised by finite automata.
A formal language is called automatical if it is equal to \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}} for some finite automaton M.
By virtue of Corollary , it does not matter at all whether Definition is understood to be referring to DFAs, NFA, or NFA\varepsilon s: the conditions are all equivalent.

When we wanted to show that different kinds of automata generated the same class of languages, we first described a method to convert between them: in particular, the subset construction converts an NFA\varepsilon to a DFA that accepts the same language, as we proved in Corollary . Today, we will use a similar strategy: we will show in § how to compile a regular expression to an NFA accepting the same language, and vice versa in [jms-017Z]; from this we will conclude Kleene’s theorem, which states that a language is regular if and only if it is automatical.

fr:title.text: Compiling a regular expression to an NFA

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Compiling a regular expression to an NFA

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We aim to show that every regular language is automatical. The rule induction principle for regular expressions implies that the regular languages are the smallest class of formal languages closed under unions, concatenation, repetition, single symbols, the empty string, and the empty language. Therefore, to prove our desired theorem it will suffice to show that the automatical languages are closed under the same constructions.

Let \Sigma be an alphabet. Then the basic regular languages {\mathopen {}\left \{a\right \}\mathclose {}} = \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (a\right )\mathclose {}} for a\in \Sigma , and {\mathopen {}\left \{\epsilon \right \}\mathclose {}} = \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (\underline {\epsilon }\right )\mathclose {}}, and \varnothing = \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (\varnothing \right )\mathclose {}} are all automatical.
For the symbol a\in \Sigma , we choose the following very simple DFA:
For the empty string, we have a simple NFA with no transitions at all (this would be an example of where the corresponding DFA would be somewhat unnatural):
For the empty language, we have the following NFA with no accepting states:
If L_1 and L_2 are automatical languages over a common alphabet \Sigma , then so is their union L_1\cup L_2.

Let M_1 and M_2 be finite automata with \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M_i\right )\mathclose {}}=L_i; without loss of generality, we assume these have disjoint sets of states. We shall describe an NFA\varepsilon M with \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}=\mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M_1\right )\mathclose {}}\cup \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M_2\right )\mathclose {}}.
We define an accepting state of M above to be either an accepting state of M_1 or of M_2. F_{M} = F_{M_1}\cup F_{M_2}

That \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}=\mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M_1\right )\mathclose {}}\cup \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M_2\right )\mathclose {}} holds follows by a quick inspection: indeed, if u\in \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M_i\right )\mathclose {}} then we have a path in M_i from \star {M_i} to an accepting state in M_i, which we can extend by means of either \varepsilon -transition to a path in M. Conversely, any from q_0 to an accepting state of M must either be a path to an accepting state of some M_i and must therefore pass through one of the two \varepsilon -transitions. Chop off that transition to get a valid path in either M_1 or M_2.
That \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}=\mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M_1\right )\mathclose {}}\mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M_2\right )\mathclose {}} holds by inspection.
If L_1 and L_2 are automatical languages over a common alphabet \Sigma , then so is their concatenation L_1L_2, which we defined below:

Let M_1 and M_2 be finite automata with \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M_i\right )\mathclose {}}=L_i; without loss of generality, we assume that these have disjoint sets of states. We shall describe an NFA\varepsilon M with \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}=\mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M_1\right )\mathclose {}}\mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M_2\right )\mathclose {}}; in particular, we lay out M_1 and M_2 side by side and draw an \varepsilon -transition from every accepting node of M_1 to the staring node of M_2.
The starting node of M is that of M_1 and the accepting nodes of M are those of M_2.
That \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}=\mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M_1\right )\mathclose {}}\mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M_2\right )\mathclose {}} holds by inspection.
If L is an automatical language over a given alphabet \Sigma , then so is the repetition L^\star of L, which we define below in terms of concatenation:

Let M be a finite automaton with \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}=L. We shall describe an NFA\varepsilon M^\star satisfying \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M^\star \right )\mathclose {}}=L^\star ; we take M and add a new starting state q_0 with an \varepsilon -transition to the old starting state, and then we make an \epsilon -transition from every old accepting state back to q_0.
The only accepting state of M^\star is q_0.
It holds by inspection that \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M^\star \right )\mathclose {}}=\mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}^\star .
If a language L is regular, then it is automatical.

Let U be the set of all regular expressions R over a fixed alphabet \Sigma such that \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (R\right )\mathclose {}} is automatical. We wish to show that the set of all regular expressions over \Sigma is contained in U. By rule induction it suffices to check the following cases:

html:ol.html:li: We need to know that \texttt {Sym}_{a},\texttt {Null}, \texttt {Never} \in U, which is the same as to say that the languages {\mathopen {}\left \{a\right \}\mathclose {}}, {\mathopen {}\left \{\epsilon \right \}\mathclose {}}, \varnothing are all automatical. This is Lemma .

We need to show that if R,S\in U then \texttt {Union}{\mathopen {}\left (R,S\right )\mathclose {}}\in U, which is to say that the language \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (R\right )\mathclose {}}\cup \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (S\right )\mathclose {}} is automatical assuming that \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (R\right )\mathclose {}} and \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (S\right )\mathclose {}} are. This is Lemma .

We need to show that if R,S\in U then \texttt {Concat}{\mathopen {}\left (R,S\right )\mathclose {}}\in U, which is to say that the language \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (R\right )\mathclose {}}\mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (S\right )\mathclose {}} = {\mathopen {}\left \{uv\,\middle \vert \,u\in \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (R\right )\mathclose {}},v\in \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (S\right )\mathclose {}}\right \}\mathclose {}} is automatical assuming that \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (R\right )\mathclose {}} and \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (S\right )\mathclose {}} are. This is Lemma .

We need to show that if R\in U then so is \texttt {Star}{\mathopen {}\left (R\right )\mathclose {}}\in U, which is to say that if \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (R\right )\mathclose {}} is automatical then so is \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (R\right )\mathclose {}}^\star . This is Lemma .

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We are done.

fr:title.text: Decompiling a regular expression from an NFA

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Decompiling a regular expression from an NFA

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We want to “decompile” any NFA to an equivalent regular expression; it is not easy to do so directly, so we will actually solve a more general problem first.
Let M be an NFA. A region of M is defined to be a triple {\mathopen {}\left (q,S,q'\right )\mathclose {}} with S\subseteq Q_{M} and q,q'\in Q_{M}.

A region {\mathopen {}\left (q,S,q'\right )\mathclose {}} in an NFA M is meant to encode a language whose strings consist of those that can be consumed starting from states q and ending in state q' passing only through states that lie in S. We define this more formally below.

fr:title.text: The formal language accepted within a region

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The formal language accepted within a region

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let {\mathopen {}\left (q,S,q'\right )\mathclose {}} be a region in an NFA M. The formal language accepted within {\mathopen {}\left (q,S,q'\right )\mathclose {}} is defined to be the following set of strings:
We shall also refer to \mathcal {L}_{M}{\mathopen {}\left (q,S,q'\right )\mathclose {}} as the regional language of M in {\mathopen {}\left (q,S,q'\right )\mathclose {}}.
Any regional language of an NFA is regular.
We proceed by induction on the number of elements in S.

In the base case, we know that S is empty; the regional language \mathcal {L}_{M}{\mathopen {}\left (q,\varnothing ,q'\right )\mathclose {}} therefore consist of those strings u such that either u=\epsilon and q=q', or u=a for some a\in \Sigma _M and q\mathrel {\xrightarrow {a}}q'. Writing this more formally, we have:
The above is a finite union of regular languages, and so it is evidently regular.

In the inductive step, we assume that any regional language whose interior state set has n elements is regular, and we must show the same for any regional language whose interior state set has n+1 elements. Fixing such a region {\mathopen {}\left (q,S,q'\right )\mathclose {}} with \#S=n+1, we will try to reduce the \mathcal {L}_{M}{\mathopen {}\left (q,S,q'\right )\mathclose {}} to something in terms languages that we know by our inductive hypothesis to be regular. Our strategy is to simply remove an arbitrary element from S.

To that end, we pick some arbitrary q_0\in S so that the set difference S' = S\setminus {\mathopen {}\left \{q_0\right \}\mathclose {}} has n elements. IF we think about all the ways taht we could get from q to q' passing through states lying only in S, there are a two possibilities in relation to the state q_0:

html:ol.html:li: We might have never pass through q_0 at all. This would correspond to the regional language \mathcal {L}_{M}{\mathopen {}\left (q,S',q'\right )\mathclose {}}, which we know to be regular by our induction hypothesis.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We see the following by inspection:
As regular languages are closed under finite unions, we are done.
Any automatical language is regular.

We have shown in Lemma that each regional langauge of an NFA is regular; regular languages are closed under finite unions, so it suffices to decompose \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}} into a finite union of regional languages \mathcal {L}_{M}{\mathopen {}\left (q,S,q'\right )\mathclose {}}.

We note that if a string is accepted by M, it does so by means of a path from the starting state to some accepting state; each of these scenarios for a given accepting state specifies a region {\mathopen {}\left (s_{M},Q_{M},q\right )\mathclose {}} with q\in F_{M}. Therefore, we immediately deduce:
Therefore it follows that \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}} is regular.
We now come to the main result of this lecture.
A formal language is regular if and only if it is automatical.
By Corollary and Corollary .

In light of the above, we will from now on refer mainly to regular languages, and leave behind the non-standard terminology of “automatical languages”. Several questions that we left unanswered (see Discussion ) can now be addressed in light of Kleene’s theorem.
Let R be a regular expression over an alphabet \Sigma . Then there exists an algorithm to compute whether a given string u\in \Sigma ^\star matches R.

The idea of the proof is to find a DFA M satisfying \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}=\mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (R\right )\mathclose {}}; so for this we need only Corollary rather than the full Kleene’s theorem. Then our algorithm is to feed the given string u through M and check whether the final state is accepting or not.

There is a subtlety in the argument above: we need the DFA M to have computably decidable equality of states. The way to deal with this is that M has a finite set of states, and so isomorphic to a standard finite set of the form \mathbb {N}_{<n}, which has computably decidable equality. A more important subtlety is that we need it to be computably decidable whether a given state is an accepting state, and we also need the transition function to be computable; any subset of a finite set is going to be decidable for roughly the same reason—ahead of time, we can enumerate it as a list of numbers in \mathbb {N}_{<n}.

fr:title.text: Closure of regular languages under complementation

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Closure of regular languages under complementation

fr:mainmatter.html:p: If L is a regular language over an alphabet \Sigma , then so is its complement \Sigma ^\star \setminus L.

Let L be a regular language, and so by Kleene’s theorem we have some DFA M satisfying L=\mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}. We define a new DFA \lnot {M} satisfying \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (\lnot {M}\right )\mathclose {}} = \Sigma ^\star \setminus L by setting \lnot {M} to have the same states, transition function, and starting state as M but with the opposite set of accepting states:
The desired property of \lnot {M} is immediate.

fr:title.text: Closure of regular languages under intersection

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Closure of regular languages under intersection

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The intersection of two regular languages over a fixed alphabet \Sigma is regular.
We fix regular languages L_1,L_2\subseteq \Sigma ^\star and consider the intersection L_1\cap L_2. By De Morgan’s laws, we have:

Because regular languages are closed under complementation, it suffices to check that {\mathopen {}\left ( \Sigma ^\star \setminus L_1 \right )\mathclose {}}\cup {\mathopen {}\left ( \Sigma ^\star \setminus L_2 \right )\mathclose {}} is regular. Regular languages are, by definition, closed under finite unions, so it remains to check that the complements \Sigma ^\star \setminus L_1 and \Sigma ^\star \setminus L_2 are regular. This follows from our assumption that L_1 and L_2 are regular via closure under complements.

It is decidable whether two regular expressions R,S over a fixed alphabet \Sigma are equivalent in the sense that \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (R\right )\mathclose {}}=\mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (S\right )\mathclose {}}.
We note that two subsets are equal if and only if the intersection of one with the complement of the other is empty, and vice versa:

We therefore let M and N be two DFAs recognising the language {\mathopen {}\left (\Sigma ^\star \setminus \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (R\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}\cap \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (S\right )\mathclose {}} and {\mathopen {}\left (\Sigma ^\star \setminus \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (S\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}\cap \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (R\right )\mathclose {}} respectively. (These DFAs can be obtained computably using the compilation procedure by which we proved Corollary .) It follows then that \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (R\right )\mathclose {}}=\mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (S\right )\mathclose {}} if and only if \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}=\varnothing =\mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (N\right )\mathclose {}}.

So it now remains to check whether there exists any string at all that is accepted by M and likewise for N. We do not have to check all strings over \Sigma , which would be impossible: we observe that the number of states in M bounds the number of transitions required to reach an accepting state, because any loops about a state q can be excised from the path without changing the result. This is a special property of the finite automata that we have studied so far, corresponding to the fact that they have no memory.

A (binary) relation R from a set A to a set B, written R\colon A\mathbin {\nrightarrow } B or R\in \mathrm {Rel}{\mathopen {}\left (A,B\right )\mathclose {}} is defined to be a subset R\subseteq A\times B. We shall typically write a\mathrel {R}b for {\mathopen {}\left (a,b\right )\mathclose {}}\in R. More generally, a relation between multiple sets {\mathopen {}\left (A_i\right )\mathclose {}}_{i\in I} is defined to be a subset of the cartesian product \prod _{i\in I} A_i.

Let A and B be two sets, and let R,S\colon A\mathbin {\nrightarrow } B be two relations from A to B. Then we have R=S if and only if \forall {a\in A}\mathpunct {.} \forall {b\in B}\mathpunct {.} a\mathrel {R}b\Longleftrightarrow a\mathrel {S}b.

We recall that relation from A to B is nothing more than a subset of A\times B. By the axiom of extensionality, two subsets of A\times B are equal if and only if they contain precisely the same elements.

fr:title.text: Uses of relations in computer science

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Uses of relations in computer science

fr:mainmatter.html:p: In the simplest terms, a specification of a program is a relation that describes the possible input/output pairs that can occur. For example, the specification that a given program compute the square root is captured by the relation \mathsf {sq} \colon \mathbb {R}_{\geq 0} \mathbin {\nrightarrow } \mathbb {R} given by pairs {\mathopen {}\left (x,y\right )\mathclose {}} such that x = y^2.

Let E represent the set of states in a machine; then the behavior of this machine is usually described by a pair of relations S \colon E\mathbin {\nrightarrow } E and V\colon E\mathbin {\nrightarrow } {\mathopen {}\left \{\star \right \}\mathclose {}}, such that e\mathrel {S} e' when it is possible for the machine to transition from state e to e' and such that e\mathrel {V} \star when the machine can halt in state e.

Let E be the set of expression in a given programming language, and let T be the set of types in that programming language. Then the property of a given program having a certain type forms a relation E\mathbin {\nrightarrow } T.

Let e,e' be two programs of type \tau . We say that e and e' are observationally equivalent when for any other program h\colon \tau \to {\mathopen {}\left (\right )\mathclose {}}, then h{\mathopen {}\left (e\right )\mathclose {}} terminates if and only if h{\mathopen {}\left (e'\right )\mathclose {}} terminates. If E_\tau is the set of programs of type \tau , observational equivalence therefore forms a relation E_\tau \mathbin {\nrightarrow } E_\tau .
A network is given by a set of nodes N and a relation C\colon N\mathbin {\nrightarrow } N expressing with two nodes are connected.

We now come to an example of a relation between multiple sets: we could define a relation R\subseteq \text {Movies}\times \text {Directors}\times \text {Years}\times \text {People} consisting of tuples {\mathopen {}\left (m,d,y,p\right )\mathclose {}} where m is a movie directed by d in year y with p as a cast member.
For any two sets A and B, we may form the empty relation \varnothing \colon A\mathbin {\nrightarrow } B that relates no elements. In other words, \varnothing is the empty subset of A\times B.

For any two sets A and B, we may form the full relation {\mathopen {}\left (A\times B\right )\mathclose {}}\colon A\mathbin {\nrightarrow } B, also called the total relation, so that a\mathrel {{\mathopen {}\left (A\times B\right )\mathclose {}}}b for all a\in A and b\in B. In other words, {\mathopen {}\left (A\times B\right )\mathclose {}} is the total subset of A\times B.

For any set A, we can form the identity relation \mathsf {id}_{A}\colon A\mathbin {\nrightarrow } A, also called the equality relation, which relates each element of A to itself. In other words, we have a\mathrel {\mathsf {id}_{A}} a' if and only if a=a'.

We have already seen the square root relation from positive reals to reals, which corresponds to a total but many-valued function. We can define an analogous relationship in Example below from positive integers (naturals) to integers, which will correspond to a partial and many-valued function.
The square root operation corresponds to a relation R_2\colon \mathbb {N}\mathbin {\nrightarrow }\mathbb {Z} such that m\mathrel {R_2} n if and only if m = n^2.

A directed graph {\mathopen {}\left (A,R\right )\mathclose {}} consists of a set A and a binary relation R\colon A\mathbin {\nrightarrow } A from A to itself; such a relation from a set to itself is called an endo-relation. We will abbreviate \mathrm {Rel}{\mathopen {}\left (A,A\right )\mathclose {}} by \mathrm {Rel}{\mathopen {}\left (A\right )\mathclose {}} for the set of all endo-relations on A.
For every set A, the structure {\mathopen {}\left (\mathrm {Rel}{\mathopen {}\left (A\right )\mathclose {}},\mathsf {id}_{A},\circ \right )\mathclose {}} given by endo-relations is a monoid.
We have seen in Lemma that relational composition is associative and has identity relations \mathsf {id}_{A} as neutral elements.

Let {\mathopen {}\left (A,R\right )\mathclose {}} be a directed graph. For s,t\in A, a path of length n\in \mathbb {N} in R with source s and target t is a tuple {\mathopen {}\left (a_0,\ldots ,a_n\right )\mathclose {}}\in A^{n+1} such that a_0=s, a_n=t, and a_i\mathrel {R}a_{i+1} for all 0\leq i <n.
Let A,R be a directed graph. For all n\in \mathbb {N} and s,t\in A, we have s\mathrel {R^{\circ n}}t if and only if there exists a path of length n in R with source s and target t.
Let P(n) be the proposition that for all s,t\in A we have s\mathrel {R^{\circ n}}t if and only if there exists a path of length n in R with source s and target t.
We shall prove P{\mathopen {}\left (n\right )\mathclose {}} for all n by induction.

html:ol.html:li: In the base case, we must prove P{\mathopen {}\left (0\right )\mathclose {}}: this states for for all s,t\in A, we have s=t if and only if there exists a path in R of length 0 from s to t. This holds by definition of paths, considering the unary tuple.

In the inductive step, we may assume P{\mathopen {}\left (n\right )\mathclose {}} to prove P{\mathopen {}\left (n+1\right )\mathclose {}}. Fixing s,t\in A we must show that s \mathrel {R^{\circ {\mathopen {}\left (n+1\right )\mathclose {}}}} t if and only if there exists a path of length n+1 in R. By definition, we have s \mathrel {R^{\circ {\mathopen {}\left (n+1\right )\mathclose {}}}} t if and only if there exists s' such that s\mathrel {R}s' and s'\mathrel {R^{\circ n}} t. By our inductive hypothesis P{\mathopen {}\left (0\right )\mathclose {}} applied to s',t, the latter holds if and only if there exists a path of length n from s' to t in R. As we can extend such a path by the link s\mathrel {R}s', we are done.

In the case of an endo-relation R\in \mathrm {Rel}{\mathopen {}\left ({\mathopen {}\left [n\right ]\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}, the reflexive-transitive closure R^{\circ *} can be computed using a finite union rather over m \leq n rather than an infinite union over all of \mathbb {N}; in particular, we have R^{\circ *} = \bigcup _{k \leq n} R^{\circ k}.

There are only n distinct elements that could be related, so there cannot be a chain of distinct elements with length o>n, and any finite path in R from s to t can be replaced by one that has no repetitions.

A preorder {\mathopen {}\left (P,\sqsubseteq \right )\mathclose {}} consists of a set P and a relation {\sqsubseteq } \colon P\mathbin {\nrightarrow } P satisfying the following two axioms:

html:li.fr:tex: \forall x,y,z\in P\mathpunct {.} {\mathopen {}\left (x\sqsubseteq y\land y \sqsubseteq z\right )\mathclose {}}\implies x\sqsubseteq z

fr:mainmatter.html:p: In other words, a preorder is a directed graph such that the edge relation is both reflexive and transitive.
Preorders are everywhere in both general mathematics and computer science.

html:ol.html:li: The real numbers equipped with their inequality relation form a preorder \mathbb {R},\leq . The converse relation {\mathopen {}\left (\mathbb {R},\geq \right )\mathclose {}} of course also forms a preorder. This example can be specialised to different classes of numbers, such as integers or naturals.

Subsets with their inclusion and containment relations form preorders {\mathopen {}\left (\mathcal {P}(A),\subseteq \right )\mathclose {}} and {\mathopen {}\left (\mathcal {P}(A),\supseteq \right )\mathclose {}}. This example can be specialised to other examples that have additional structure, such as the preorder \mathcal {P}_f(A) of finite subsets of a given set A, or the preorder \mathcal {O}(X) of open sets of a topological space X.

A slightly more nontrivial example is furnished by the preorder {\mathopen {}\left (\mathbb {Z},{\mid }\right )\mathclose {}} of the integers and the divisibility relation, where m\mid n if and only if \exists k\in \mathbb {Z}\mathpunct {.} m k = n: indeed, we certainly have n divides n, and if l divides m and m divides n, then l divides m.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The first example above happen to be total orders (meaning that the underlying directed graph is connected): so {\mathopen {}\left (\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (A\right )\mathclose {}},\subseteq \right )\mathclose {}} and {\mathopen {}\left (\mathbb {Z},{\mid }\right )\mathclose {}} are example of non-total preorders.

All the examples we have seen so far are, furthermore, partial orders: a preorder is a partial order when we have a \sqsubseteq b \land b \sqsubseteq a if and only if a=b. In fact, there are arguably very few useful preorders that are not partial orders, and it is always possible to replace a preorder by an equivalent partial order; we do not pursue this here.

The reflexive-transitive closure R^{\circ *} of an endo-relation R\colon A\mathbin {\nrightarrow } A is, by definition, a preorder. We will show that R^{\circ *} enjoys a universal property as the smallest preorder containing R as a subrelation.
To be more precise, let \mathcal {F}_R be the set of preorders on A that contain R as a subrelation:
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \mathcal {F}_R = {\mathopen {}\left \{Q\colon A\mathbin {\nrightarrow } A\,\middle \vert \,R\subseteq Q \land \text {Q is a preorder}\right \}\mathclose {}}
fr:mainmatter.html:p: Then we have R^{\circ *}=\bigcap \mathcal {F}_R, and so the reflexive-transitive closure is the smallest preorder containing R as a subrelation. (Indeed, recall that the intersection of an intersection-closed class of relations is the smallest relation in that class.)
To show that R^{\circ *}=\bigcap \mathcal {F}_R, it suffices to check that \bigcap \mathcal {F}_R\subseteq R^{\circ *} and R^{\circ *}\subseteq \bigcap \mathcal {F}_R.

html:li.html:p: We first note that R^{\circ *}\in \mathcal {F}_R — which holds by almost by definition:

html:ol.html:li: We first need to show that R\subseteq R^{\circ *}, i.e. that when a\mathrel {R}b we have a\mathrel {R}^{\circ *}b. This is evident, as b\mathrel {R}b is a path of length 1 in R and R^{\circ *} contains all finite paths in R.

Next, we need to show that R^{\circ *} is a preorder. But this holds because R^{\circ *} contains the empty path from an element to itself, and because a path of length m from a to b can be concatenated with a path of length n from b to c to obtain a path (of length m+n) from a to c.

html:li.html:p: It follows from R\in \mathcal {F}_R that \bigcap \mathcal {F}_R\subseteq R^{\circ *}. Indeed: a\mathrel {{\mathopen {}\left (\bigcap \mathcal {F}_R\right )\mathclose {}}}b \Longleftrightarrow \forall Q\in \mathcal {F}_R\mathpunct {.} a\mathrel {Q}b So if a\mathrel {{\mathopen {}\left (\bigcap \mathcal {F}_R\right )\mathclose {}}}b and R^{\circ *}\in \mathcal {F}_R, we may choose Q := R^{\circ *} to deduce a\mathrel {R^{\circ *}}b. Therefore, \bigcap \mathcal {F}_R\subseteq R^{\circ *}.

Our second goal is to prove R^{\circ *}\subseteq \bigcap \mathcal {F}_R; by the definition of intersections, this holds if and only if \forall Q\in \mathcal {F}_R\mathpunct {.} R^{\circ *}\subseteq Q.

Fixing such a preorder Q over A containing R as a subrelation, we must prove that R^{\circ *}\subseteq Q. Recalling that R^{\circ *} is the union \bigcup _{n \in \mathbb {N}}R^{\circ n}, we see by the definition of unions that that R^{\circ *}\subseteq Q if and only if for each n\in \mathbb {N}, we have R^{\circ n} \subseteq Q. This we prove by induction on n\in \mathbb {N}.

html:ol.html:li: In the base case, we must show that R^{\circ 0} = \mathsf {id}_{A} is a subrelation of Q. This is equivalent to Q being reflexive, which we deduce from our assumption that Q is a preorder.

In the inductive step, we may assume R^{\circ n}\subseteq Q and we must prove that R^{\circ {\mathopen {}\left (n+1\right )\mathclose {}}}=R\circ R^{\circ n} is a subrelation of Q. For any a,b\in A, we have a\mathrel {{\mathopen {}\left (R\circ R^{\circ n}\right )\mathclose {}}} b if and only if there exists some c\in A such that a\mathrel {R}c and c\mathrel {R^{\circ n}} b. Because we have assumed that R\subseteq Q, we have a\mathrel {Q}c; by our inductive hypothesis, we have c\mathrel {Q}b. Becuase Q is a preorder and therefore transitive, we therefore have a\mathrel {Q}b.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Therefore, R^{\circ *} is indeed the intersection of \mathcal {F}_R.

A relation R\colon A\mathbin {\nrightarrow } B is said to be functional when it relates an element of A to at most one element of B:

We refer to a functional relation as a partial function; we often use letters like f,g to refer to partial functions rather than R,S. When we write “f\colon A\to B”, we mean that f is a partial function from A to B.

fr:title.text: Closure of partial functions under identity and composition

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Closure of partial functions under identity and composition

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Partial functions are closed under identity and composition in the following sense:

html:ol.html:li: For any set A, the identity relation \mathsf {id}_{A} \colon A\mathbin {\nrightarrow } A is functional.

For any sets A,B,C and functional relations f\colon A\mathbin {\rightharpoonup } B and g \colon B\mathbin {\rightharpoonup } C, the relational composite g\circ f \colon A\mathbin {\nrightarrow } C is functional.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: First, we prove that each identity relation \mathsf {id}_{A}\colon A\mathbin {\nrightarrow } A is functional. Fixing a,a_1,a_2\in A such that a=a_1 and a=a_2, we must show that a_1=a_2; this follows from transitivity and symmetry of equality.

Next, we fix partial functions f\colon A\mathbin {\rightharpoonup } B and g \colon B\mathbin {\rightharpoonup } C to check that g\circ f \colon A\mathbin {\nrightarrow } C is functional. Fixing a\in A and c_1,c_2\in C such that a\mathrel {{\mathopen {}\left (g\circ f\right )\mathclose {}}}c_1 and a\mathrel {{\mathopen {}\left (g\circ f\right )\mathclose {}}}c_2, we must check that c_1=c_2. By definition of the relational composite, we have b_1,b_2\in B such that a\mathrel {f}b_1\mathrel {g}c_1 and a\mathrel {f}b_2\mathrel {g}c_2. Because f\colon A\mathbin {\rightharpoonup } B is functional, we note that b_1 = b_2. Writing b=b_1=b_2, we therefore have b\mathrel {g}c_1 and b\mathrel {g}c_2. Because g\colon B\mathbin {\rightharpoonup } C is functional, we conclude that c_1=c_2.

Let f\colon A\mathbin {\rightharpoonup } B be a partial function. Given a\in A, we will write f{\mathopen {}\left (a\right )\mathclose {}}{\downarrow } to mean that f is defined at a, i.e. there exists some (necessarily unique) b\in B such that a\mathrel {f}b. When f{\mathopen {}\left (a\right )\mathclose {}}{\downarrow } holds, we may write f{\mathopen {}\left (a\right )\mathclose {}} to mean the unique b such that a\mathrel {f}b, which we shall refer to as the value of b.

fr:title.text: Domain of definition of a partial function

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Domain of definition of a partial function

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The domain of definition of a partial function f\colon A\mathbin {\rightharpoonup } B is the subset {\mathopen {}\left \{a\in A\,\middle \vert \,f{\mathopen {}\left (a\right )\mathclose {}}{\downarrow }\right \}\mathclose {}}\subseteq A spanned by elements of the domain on which the partial function is defined.

Let f,g\colon A\mathbin {\rightharpoonup } B be two partial functions. We have f=g if and only if for all a\in A, f is defined at a if and only if g is defined at a and, moreover, the value of f at a is the same as the value of g at a:

Fixing a\in A and b\in B, we assume a\mathrel {f} b to prove a\mathrel {g}b. By assumption, we deduce g{\mathopen {}\left (a\right )\mathclose {}}{\downarrow } from f{\mathopen {}\left (a\right )\mathclose {}}{\downarrow }, so there exists b'=g{\mathopen {}\left (a\right )\mathclose {}} such that a\mathrel {g}b'. By our other assumption, we know that f{\mathopen {}\left (a\right )\mathclose {}}=g{\mathopen {}\left (a\right )\mathclose {}}, so we conclude a\mathrel {g}b. The other direction works the same way.
The following are examples of partial functions:

html:ol.html:li: rational division {\div }\colon \mathbb {Q}\times \mathbb {Q}\mathbin {\rightharpoonup }\mathbb {Q} defined by {\mathopen {}\left \{{\mathopen {}\left ({\mathopen {}\left (r,s\right )\mathclose {}},t\right )\mathclose {}}\in {\mathopen {}\left (\mathbb {Q}\times \mathbb {Q}\right )\mathclose {}}\times \mathbb {Q}\,\middle \vert \,r=s\cdot t\right \}\mathclose {}} with domain of definition {\mathopen {}\left \{{\mathopen {}\left (r,s\right )\mathclose {}}\in \mathbb {Q}\times \mathbb {Q}\,\middle \vert \,s\not =0\right \}\mathclose {}};

fr:title.text: Cardinality of the set of partial functions

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Cardinality of the set of partial functions

fr:mainmatter.html:p: For all finite sets A and B, we have \mathord {\#}{\mathopen {}\left (A\mathbin {\rightharpoonup } B\right )\mathclose {}}={\mathopen {}\left (\mathord {\#}{B}+1\right )\mathclose {}}^{\mathord {\#}{A}}, recalling that \mathord {\#}{S} is the cardinality of a set S.

A partial function f\colon A\mathbin {\rightharpoonup } B associates to each element a\in A either a unique element f{\mathopen {}\left (a\right )\mathclose {}}\in B when f{\mathopen {}\left (a\right )\mathclose {}}{\downarrow }, or it associates nothing. Therefore, we have \mathord {\#}{A} many possibilities, each followed by \mathord {\#}{B}+1 many possibilities.

A partial function f\colon A\mathbin {\rightharpoonup } B is called total whenever its domain of definition coincides with its domain (source), i.e. we have f{\mathopen {}\left (a\right )\mathclose {}}{\downarrow } for all a\in A. In this case, we will write f\colon A\to B and refer to it as a function or a map. Sometimes, we redundantly refer to it as a total function.

Just as we write \mathrm {Rel}{\mathopen {}\left (A,B\right )\mathclose {}} and {\mathopen {}\left (A\mathbin {\rightharpoonup } B\right )\mathclose {}}for the sets of relations and partial functions from A to B respectively, we shall write {\mathopen {}\left (A\to B\right )\mathclose {}} for the set of functions from A to B.
Any relation R\colon A\mathbin {\nrightarrow } B is a function if and only if for all a\in A, there exists some unique b\in B such that a\mathrel {R}b.

Symbolically, our second criterion is \forall a\in A\mathpunct {.} \exists ! b\in B\mathpunct {.} a\mathrel {R}b. Unfolding the definition of unique existence, this is equivalent to \forall a\in A\mathpunct {.} {\mathopen {}\left (\forall b,b'\in B\mathpunct {.} a\mathrel {R}b\land a\mathrel {B}b'\implies b=b'\right )\mathclose {}}\land {\mathopen {}\left (\exists b\in B\mathpunct {.} a\mathrel {R}b\right )\mathclose {}} which is, by the distributivity of universal quantification over conjunction, equivalent to the claim that R is both functional and total.

fr:title.text: Cardinality of the set of functions

fr:mainmatter.html:p: For all finite sets A and B, we have \#{\mathopen {}\left (A\to B\right )\mathclose {}} = \#B^{\#A}.

A function f\colon A \to B associates to each element a\in A a single element f{\mathopen {}\left (a\right )\mathclose {}}\in B. Therefore, we have \#A possibilities, each followed by \#B possibilities.

fr:title.text: Informal examples of inductively defined functions

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Informal examples of inductively defined functions

fr:mainmatter.html:p: An inductive definition on the naturals defines a structure for each number n\in \mathbb {N} by first defining it for n=0 and then specifying how to augment a structure for n=m to a structure for n=m+1. From the point of view of computer programming, inductive definitions proceed by structural recursion. For example, addition of natural numbers can be defined by induction on the second argument (or the first, if you prefer!):
Likewise, the function \Sigma \colon \mathbb {N}\to \mathbb {N} that takes n\in \mathbb {N} to the sum \sum _{0\leq i < n}i can be defined inductively:

A section-retraction pair is defined to be a pair of functions s\colon B \to A and r\colon A \to B such that r\circ s =\mathsf {id}_{B}. In this case, s is referred to as a section of r, and r is referred to as a retraction of s.
A function f\colon A\to A is called idempotent when we have f\circ f = f.

fr:title.text: The idempotent determined by a section-retraction pair

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The idempotent determined by a section-retraction pair

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Every section-retraction pair determines an idempotent. In particular, when s\colon B\to A is a section of r\colon A \to B, the composite s\circ r\colon A\to A is idempotent.
We proceed by calculation:
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \begin {aligned} {\mathopen {}\left (s\circ r\right )\mathclose {}}\circ {\mathopen {}\left (s\circ r\right )\mathclose {}} &= s\circ {\mathopen {}\left (r\circ s\right )\mathclose {}}\circ r \\ &= s\circ \mathsf {id}_{B} \circ r \\ &= s\circ r \end {aligned}

fr:mainmatter.html:p: It happens that every idempotent arises from a section-retraction pair in the manner of Lemma .

Let f\colon A\to A be an idempotent on a set A. Let B be the subset {\mathopen {}\left \{f{\mathopen {}\left (a\right )\mathclose {}}\,\middle \vert \,a\in A\right \}\mathclose {}}\subseteq A, sometimes called the direct image of f in A. Then f\colon A\to A factors, by definition, through some unique r\colon A \to B, where r{\mathopen {}\left (x\right )\mathclose {}} = f{\mathopen {}\left (x\right )\mathclose {}} for all x\in A. We define s\colon B\to A to be be the subset inclusion.

We must check that r\circ s = \mathsf {id}_{B}; in other words, we fix b\in B to check that r{\mathopen {}\left (s{\mathopen {}\left (b\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}} = b. By definition, the subset inclusion s\colon B\to A takes b to the corresponding element s{\mathopen {}\left (b\right )\mathclose {}}\in A such that b=f{\mathopen {}\left (s{\mathopen {}\left (b\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}. By definition of r\colon A \to B, we therefore have r{\mathopen {}\left (s{\mathopen {}\left (b\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}=f{\mathopen {}\left (s{\mathopen {}\left (b\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}=b.

A function f\colon A \to B is said to be bijective or bijection whenever there exists a (necessarily unique) function g\colon B\to A (referred to as the inverse of f) that is simultaneously a retraction and a section of f\colon A \to B in the sense that g\circ f=\mathsf {id}_{A} and f\circ g = \mathsf {id}_{B}.
We will often write f^{-1}\colon B\to A for the inverse to a bijection f\colon A \to B.
To see that g\colon B\to A is unique, we fix any other g' that is simultaneously a retraction and a section of f and show that g=g':
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \begin {aligned} g &= \mathsf {id}_{A}\circ g\\ &= {\mathopen {}\left (g'\circ f\right )\mathclose {}} \circ g\\ &= g'\circ {\mathopen {}\left (f\circ g\right )\mathclose {}}\\ &= g'\circ \mathsf {id}_{B}\\ &= g' \end {aligned}

A bijection between two sets is a way of associating precisely one element of the first set with precisely one element of the second set. These associations are embodied in the functions f\colon A\to B and g\colon B\to A, and the uniqueness of the associations is expressed by the conditio that g be simultaneously a section and a retraction of f. Two sets of different cardinality can not be associated in this way, because there would always be left over elements that are not associated to any corresponding element. In this way, we see that a bijection exists between two sets if and only if they have the same cardinality.

Assuming two finite sets A,B with cardinality \mathord {\#}{A}=\mathord {\#}{B}=n, we must now count precisely how many bijections there are from A to B. To construct such a bijection, we put all the elements B into a pile. Then, for each element of A we must successively choose and then discard an element of B; we have to discard the element because we are not allowed to choose it again (for, if we did, the association would not be bijective). At the beginning (“round k=0”), there are n many choices we could make; in the next round k=1, there are n-1 many choices that we could make; in the kth round, there are n-k many choices that we could make. At the very end (after the n-1th round), we shall have constructed a bijection after making n! = \prod _{0\leq k<n} n-k choices in total. Thus the number of distinct bijections from A to B is n!.

fr:title.text: Closure of bijections under identity and composition

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Closure of bijections under identity and composition

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The identity function is a bijection, and the composition of bijections yields a bijection.
The inverse to the identity function \mathsf {id}_{A}\colon A\to A is simply itself.

Fix bijections f\colon A\to B and g\colon B\to C, so that we have inverses f^{-1}\colon B\to A and g^{-1}\colon C\to B. The inverse to the composite function g\circ f\colon A \to C is the composite f^{-1}\circ g^{-1}\colon C \to A. The section/retraction conditions follow by those for f and g using the associative and unit laws of composition.
Two sets A and B are said to be isomorphic (and have the same cardinality) whenever there is a bijection between them. In this case, we write A\cong B or \mathord {\#}{A}=\mathord {\#}{B}

A bijection between finite sets is just a “relabeling” of its elements: for example, we have {\mathopen {}\left \{0,1\right \}\mathclose {}}\cong {\mathopen {}\left \{\mathsf {false},\mathsf {true}\right \}\mathclose {}}. Isomorphism of infinite sets can be more confusing: for example, we have \mathbb {N}\cong {\mathopen {}\left \{n:\mathbb {N}\,\middle \vert \,n>0\right \}\mathclose {}}, \mathbb {N}\cong \mathbb {Z}, \mathbb {N}\cong \mathbb {N}\times \mathbb {N}, \mathbb {N}\cong \mathbb {Q}, and even {\mathopen {}\left (\mathbb {N}\to \mathbb {N}\right )\mathclose {}}\cong \mathbb {R}.

Although we are speaking of “being isomorphic” as the property of there being a bijection between them, in practice, it is almost never useful to know that there exists some undetermined bijection between given sets; it is always important to know which bijection. Indeed, we have seen in Proposition that there can be many distinct bijections between two sets.
A relation E\colon A\mathbin {\nrightarrow } A is called an equivalence relation when it is reflexive, transitive, and symmetric:
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \forall x,y,z\in A\mathpunct {.} x\mathrel {E} y \land y \mathrel {E} z \implies x \mathrel {E} z
fr:mainmatter.html:p: We will write \mathrm {EqRel}{\mathopen {}\left (A\right )\mathclose {}} for the set of all equivalence relations on A.

Let E\colon A\mathbin {\nrightarrow } A be an equivalence relation on a set A. The equivalence class of a given element a\in A in E is the subset {\mathopen {}\left [a\right ]\mathclose {}}_{E}\subseteq A spanned by elements related to a in E, i.e. {\mathopen {}\left [a\right ]\mathclose {}}_{E} = {\mathopen {}\left \{x\in A\,\middle \vert \,x\mathrel {E}a\right \}\mathclose {}}.
You may hear some people say “an equivalence” instead of “an equivalence relation”. This usage is wrong and leads to extremely confused thinking: you must not repeat it!

A partition of a set A is a set P\subseteq \mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (A\right )\mathclose {}} of non-empty subsets of A whose elements are referred to as blocks, satisfying the following conditions:

html:ol.html:li: the union of all blocks is all of A, i.e. \bigcup P = A;
the blocks are pairwise disjoint, i.e. for all b_1\not = b_2\in P we have b_1\cap b_2 = \varnothing .

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We will write \mathrm {Part}{\mathopen {}\left (A\right )\mathclose {}} for the set of partitions of A.

fr:title.text: Bijection between equivalence relations and partitions

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Bijection between equivalence relations and partitions

fr:mainmatter.html:p: For every set A, we can define a bijection \Phi \colon \mathrm {EqRel}{\mathopen {}\left (A\right )\mathclose {}}\to \mathrm {Part}{\mathopen {}\left (A\right )\mathclose {}} sending every equivalence relation E on A to the partition \Phi {\mathopen {}\left (E\right )\mathclose {}} = {\mathopen {}\left \{{\mathopen {}\left [a\right ]\mathclose {}}_{E}\,\middle \vert \,a\in A\right \}\mathclose {}} whose blocks consist of the equivalence classes of each element of A.

We must first argue that {\mathopen {}\left \{{\mathopen {}\left [a\right ]\mathclose {}}_{E}\,\middle \vert \,a\in A\right \}\mathclose {}} in fact constitutes a partition; the union of all equivalence classes is indeed all of A, and we can see that any two distinct equivalence classes have null intersection — since, if there were an intersection, the two equivalence classes would be identical.
The inverse \Phi ^{-1} sends a partition P to the following equivalence relation:
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: x \mathrel {{\mathopen {}\left (\Phi ^{-1}{\mathopen {}\left (P\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}} y\Longleftrightarrow \exists b\in P\mathpunct {.} x\in b \land y \in b
fr:mainmatter.html:p: To check that \Phi ^{-1} is a section of \Phi , we fix a partition P to check that \Phi {\mathopen {}\left (\Phi ^{-1}{\mathopen {}\left (P\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}} = P.

As P is a partition, there is exactly one block containing a given element a\in A — no more than one by disjointness, and no fewer than one because the union of a partition must be the entire set. Therefore, the set {\mathopen {}\left \{x\in A\,\middle \vert \,\exists b\in P\mathpunct {.} x\in b \land a \in b\right \}\mathclose {}} is precisely the unique block of P containing a. Thus we have \Phi {\mathopen {}\left (\Phi ^{-1}{\mathopen {}\left (P\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}} = P.

Now that we have learned about bijections, we are ready to replace our intuitive/informal understanding of finite sets and finite cardinality with a formal one.

A set A is said to be finite or have finite cardinality when it is isomorphic to a set of the form {\mathopen {}\left [n\right ]\mathclose {}} for some n\in \mathbb {N}; in this case, we therefore have \mathord {\#}{A}=n. (Recall that {\mathopen {}\left [n\right ]\mathclose {}} is the standard n-element set {\mathopen {}\left \{i\in \mathbb {N}\,\middle \vert \,0\leq i < n\right \}\mathclose {}}.)
There are many identities that relate set-theoretic operations on finite sets to arithmetic operations on their cardinalities. We will illustrate a few of them here.
For all m,n\in \mathbb {N}, we have {\mathopen {}\left [m\right ]\mathclose {}}\times {\mathopen {}\left [n\right ]\mathclose {}} \cong {\mathopen {}\left [m\cdot n\right ]\mathclose {}}.
We can prove this from a combinatoric point of view.

To choose a pair {\mathopen {}\left (i,j\right )\mathclose {}}\in {\mathopen {}\left [m\right ]\mathclose {}}\times {\mathopen {}\left [n\right ]\mathclose {}}, we first choose an element of {\mathopen {}\left [m\right ]\mathclose {}} and we second choose an element of {\mathopen {}\left [n\right ]\mathclose {}}. There are m possibilities for the first choice and n possibilities for the second choice; as these choices are independent, we simply have m\cdot n choices in total.
We can also prove this isomorphism more formally by means of a specific bijection.

We can think of the cartesian product {\mathopen {}\left [m\right ]\mathclose {}}\times {\mathopen {}\left [n\right ]\mathclose {}} as the set of cells in table or matrix with m columns and n rows — and then an element {\mathopen {}\left (i,j\right )\mathclose {}} with i\in {\mathopen {}\left [m\right ]\mathclose {}} and j\in {\mathopen {}\left [n\right ]\mathclose {}} is the coordinate of a given cell. An alphabet is specified by giving a finite set \Sigma whose elements are called symbols. Any finite set can serve as an alphabet as far as we are concerned.

Let \Sigma be an alphabet. A string of length n over \Sigma is defined to be an n-tuple of elements of \Sigma . We write these without any punctuation between them. The set of all strings (of any length) over \Sigma is written \Sigma ^\star ; for a string u\in \Sigma ^\star , we will write {\mathopen {}\left \lvert u\right \rvert \mathclose {}}\in \mathbb {N} for its length.

Strings over a fixed alphabet \Sigma can be concatenated. When u,v\in \Sigma ^\star are two strings over \Sigma , their concatenation is denoted uv\in \Sigma ^\star and is obtained by joining them end-to-end.
For example, if u=ab and v=ba then uv = abba.

We are now ready to define what a formal language is. We are used to thinking of languages as being defined by a grammar, but a more abstract or “extensional” point of view is that a formal language is nothing more than the set of strings it generates. We adopt that perspective below.
A formal language over an alphabet \Sigma is defined to be a subset of \Sigma ^\star , i.e. a set of strings over \Sigma .

Although we have defined formal languages in this very extensional manner, “rules of grammar” still plays a role: in particular, we will use inductive definitions of grammatical rules to generate formal languages by building on our prior experience with inductive definitions:

fr:mainmatter.html:p: In what remains of this lecture, we will be studying strategies for defining and using inductive definitions of subsets of a given set.
In many cases, a subset is defined implicitly by describing the rules that you must follow in order to construct an element of it.
For example, consider the set of natural numbers \mathbb {N} viewed as a subset of the reals \mathbb {R}; this could be described by the following rules of construction:

html:ol.html:li: 0 is a natural number.
If x is a natural number, then x+1 is also a natural number.

In this course, we are particularly interested in the class of formal languages that can be recognised by regular expressions, and later on we will develop tools that allow us to show that some formal languages are too complex to be recognised by regular expressions. html:ol.html:li: Is there an algorithm which, given a string u and a regular expression r, computes whether or not u matches r?
In formulating the definition of regular expressions, have we missed out on some practically useful notions of pattern?
Is there an algorithm that will compute whether two regular expressions generate the same language?
Is every formal language of generated by a regular expression?

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We will come back to these questions in subsequent lectures. In the meantime, we can say:

html:ol.html:li: Is there an algorithm which, given a string u and a regular expression r, computes whether or not u matches r? Yes. One very simple way is to simply use the rules of Definition as a search algorithm, but this is not very efficient; better ways to decide regular expression matching can be achieved using finite automata, which we will study in the next lecture.

In formulating the definition of regular expressions, have we missed out on some practically useful notions of pattern? Yes! For example, it can be useful to specify a range of symbols (including all symbols!) over an alphabet like most practical regular expression libraries allow. A more sophisticated example is complementation, where a string matches \mathord {\sim }(r) if and only if it does not match r. We will ultimately see that the complement of any regular expression already exists—but it can be useful to include it as a built-in feature.
Is there an algorithm that will compute whether two regular expressions generate the same language? Yes, but we will need the theory of finite automata to see that this is the case.
Is every formal language of generated by a regular expression? No: we will ultimately learn a technique, called the pumping lemma to find counter-examples.

In this lecture, we introduce our a fundamental mathematical model of computatation: the finite automaton.
The most basic form of automaton is the non-deterministic finite automaton as defined below.
A non-deterministic finite automaton or NFA for short is defined to be a tuple M = {\mathopen {}\left (Q,\Sigma ,\Delta ,s,F\right )\mathclose {}} where:

html:ol.html:li: Q is a finite set (of “states”).
\Sigma is an alphabet, i.e. a finite set.
\Delta is a ternary relation \Delta \colon Q\times \Sigma \mathbin {\nrightarrow } Q called the transition relation: we write q\xrightarrow {a}{q'} to mean that (q,a,q')\in \Delta .
s is an element of Q, the “starting state”.
F is a subset of Q, the “accepting states”.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The idea of an NFA is that you “feed” it a string after initialising it to its starting state, and then you explore the transitions it makes by biting off characters from the string until it is consumed. If the automaton ends up in an accepting state then the string is accepted; otherwise, the string is considered rejected. More formally:

fr:title.text: The formal language accepted by an NFA

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The formal language accepted by an NFA

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let M=(Q,\Sigma ,\Delta ,s,F) be a non-deterministic finite automaton over an alphabet \Sigma . Then the formal language accepted by M is defined to be the subset \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}\subseteq \Sigma ^\star specified as follows:
For the above, we define the relation q\mathrel {\vphantom {\xrightarrow {u}}\smash {\xrightarrow {u}}^*} q' by induction on the string u:
This is similar to reflexive-transitive closure in a directed graph, except that the edges of our graph are labelled by symbols from the alphabet \Sigma .

NFAs represent an extremely limited but nonetheless useful form of computational power; intuitively, this is because they don’t have any memory. It is therefore an interesting theorem when a language can be recognised by an NFA. In this lecture we will show that (1) NFAs can be given some more capabilities without changing the class of languages they recognise, and (2) the non-determinism of the transition relation is not necessary. Having more capabilities is helpful when constructing an automaton, but having fewer capabilities is helpful when investigating the class of all automata.

NFAs are usually drawn in a graphical notation that depicts the states as circled nodes, with possible transitions given by arrows between the nodes. The starting state is drawn with an arrow pointing from it out of nowhere, and the accepting states are drawn in double-struck circles. For example, consider the following picture:
The picture above depicts an NFA accepting the following formal language over the alphabet \Sigma ={\mathopen {}\left \{a,b\right \}\mathclose {}}:

Indeed, from the initial state we can consume as many as and bs as we like but at some point we must transition along an a to q_1 after which we have no choice but to consume two as until we reach an accepting state q_3. At this point, we can continue with as many as and bs as we like (an accepting state does not have to be a terminal state!).

A deterministic finite automaton or DFA for short is an NFA for which the transition relation \Delta \colon Q\times \Sigma \mathbin {\nrightarrow } Q is a function, i.e. a total and functional relation. This states, in other words, that to each state each state q\in Q can transition along each symbol a\in \Sigma to one and only one state, which we conventionally write \delta {\mathopen {}\left (q,a\right )\mathclose {}}. Indeed, we will often write M = (Q,\Sigma ,\delta ,s,F) for a DFA. In this case, we have q \mathrel {\xrightarrow {a}}q' if and only if \delta {\mathopen {}\left (q,a\right )\mathclose {}}=q'.

As an aside, it might feel strange to speak of “deterministic non-deterministic finite automata”. This is OK but can take some getting used to: mathematicians have discovered over the past several centuries that it is better for negations in terminology to mean “not necessarily” rather than “definitely not”; this is similar to the way that mathematicians often say “greater than” to mean “greater than or equal to”, reserving “strictly greater than” for the notion that excludes equality.
An NFA can fail to be deterministic in just two ways:

html:ol.html:li: There could be a pair (q,a) for which there exists no transition q\mathrel {\xrightarrow {a}}q'.
There could be a pair (q,a) such that q\mathrel {\xrightarrow {a}}q' and q\mathrel {\xrightarrow {a}}q'' for distinct states q',q''\in Q.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We recall our sample NFA over \Sigma ={\mathopen {}\left \{a,b\right \}\mathclose {}} from Example fails to be deterministic in both ways: we have both q_0\mathrel {\xrightarrow {a}}q_0 and q_0\mathrel {\xrightarrow {a}}q_1, and moreover there is no transition along b from state q_1 and q_2.
We could make the automaton deterministic by removing some transitions and adding others, while still accepting the same language:

So the above is a DFA over \Sigma . But if were to view it as an NFA over the extended alphabet \Sigma ' = {\mathopen {}\left \{a,b,c\right \}\mathclose {}}, then it would again fail to be deterministic because there would be no transitions along c!

We will ultimately show that every NFA can be transformed into a more complicated DFA that accepts the same language. But before we do so, we introduce a further strengthening of the features of NFAs that can be reduced directly to DFAs in one go.

A non-deterministic finite automaton with \varepsilon -transitions or NFA\varepsilon for short is an NFA M = {\mathopen {}\left (Q,\Sigma ,\Delta ,s,F\right )\mathclose {}} together with an additional relation T\colon Q\mathbin {\nrightarrow } Q called the \varepsilon -transition relation.

We will write q\mathrel {\xrightarrow {\varepsilon }}q' to mean that q\mathrel {T}q'. This notation is a little confusing! Note that this \varepsilon is not the same as the \epsilon denoting the empty string, and that therefore q\mathrel {\xrightarrow {\varepsilon }}q' means something very different from q\mathrel {\vphantom {\xrightarrow {\epsilon }}\smash {\xrightarrow {\epsilon }}^*} q'.
The purpose of the \varepsilon -transition relation in an NFA\varepsilon is to allow the automaton to transition to states without consuming a symbol.
The graphical notation of NFAs that we introduced in Example can be extended to handle \varepsilon -transitions in a straightforward way. For example:

In Definition we described the formal language accepted by an NFA in terms of a labelled path relation q\mathrel {\vphantom {\xrightarrow {u}}\smash {\xrightarrow {u}}^*} q'. Below, we give an analogous definition that accounts for \varepsilon -transitions.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The formal language accepted by an NFA\varepsilon

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let M=(Q,\Sigma ,\Delta ,s,F,T) be an NFA\varepsilon . The formal lanuage accepted by M is defined to be the subset \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}\subseteq \Sigma ^\star specified as follows:

Above we define the relation q\mathrel {\xRightarrow {u}} q' to mean that there exists a path through M from q to q' whose non-\varepsilon -transitions consume the string u. In more formal terms, we can define the relation inductively by rules:
